website_summaries.verdict: While some had issues with its durability, this is an extremely affordable option that you can upgrade by picking and choosing from a variety of survival tools.
pros: A number of different kits come with option such as a knife, compass, fire starter, and pocket tool
Three foot by seven foot size, and weights 5.8 ounces
Constructed of a heavy-duty aluminized PE interior material
Priced very low, and includes a drawstring carry bag
cons: Some buyers report that the material is very thin and tears easily

customer_reviews.title: This product helped me save a life today
customer_reviews.text: This product helped me save a life today. I was driving on the freeway this morning when the car in front of me lost control and crashed. One of the passengers was going into shock and we had to lay her down. It’s been getting cold lately and laying a shock patient on the cold ground is a bad idea. I remembered keeping this in my car and broke it out. It kept the patient warm until the ambulance arrived. I can honestly say this product does what it says on the label.
customer_reviews.author: Keith H

customer_reviews.title: anybody that travels outdoors should carry one with them. I and a Homeless Person Highly Recommend this product.
customer_reviews.text: Bought one of these sleeping bags for a homeless person last winter 2013. He told me he would get so warm he'd open to exchange the air to cool off.
customer_reviews.author: Richard D. Will

customer_reviews.title: Good alternative.  Reflects body heat well.
customer_reviews.text: Comparable to the SOL, this does the trick for less money. It is a bit heavier than the SOL (which I also have) but it does the same thing. I have this one in a get home bag and I feel comfortable that it will not fail when needed. One tip, keep your head outside of the bag if at all possible. The moisture in your breath will condensate and cause wetness in the bag.
customer_reviews.author: Mike

customer_reviews.title: Boo this bivvy.
customer_reviews.text: I wound up needing this as a back-up plan in the White Mountains last night. Total fail. My feet went through it and the thing was in shreds in no time. It was a cold night - thanks for nothing.
customer_reviews.author: Gnar Gnar

customer_reviews.title: Didn't Work For Me at All
customer_reviews.text: I just bought this item about a week ago. Threw it in the car, just in case. Got stuck in gridlocked traffic last night due to a snowstorm. Decided to try it out. Immediately put two lengthwise tears in it upon getting inside. So, frankly it became useless to me. Might be able to cut it into strips next summer to keep the starlings out of my garden. ;)
customer_reviews.author: Joe Schild

customer_reviews.title: Not satisfied
customer_reviews.text: I took it out in the field for testing and it just ripped easy. Not a great material
customer_reviews.author: Randy Gonzalez

customer_reviews.title: Cheap insurance
customer_reviews.text: This sleeping bag is okay, I would prefer to spend $5 more and get the SOL Bivvy sack that this is trying to compete with. The material does not feel as quality as the SOL. It did not tear upon tested entry of the bag and did roll up nice fitting back into the little provided sack, but it is definitely going to be a one time use bag. The SOL Bivvy is a little better built and can get a few uses out of each one but don't expect it to be a full time sleeping bag. I buy these as cheap insurance while camping if the temps drops and I need some extra warmth.
customer_reviews.author: Zach

customer_reviews.title: Kept me warm when my sleeping bag didn't
customer_reviews.text: My sleeping bag wasn't as warm as advertised so I had to use the bivy to keep me warm(er). It did its job, but I'm still not sure what's the right way to do it. When I put it inside my sleeping bag, my clothes would be damp the next morning. When I put it outside the sleeping bag, I would wake up and the bivy was full of condensate on the inside. I was sleeping in a hammock which I'm not sure is a good idea on 42F nights. But the bivy definitely helped.
customer_reviews.author: P. Roth

customer_reviews.title: Silver coating rubbed off partly with water condensation problem
customer_reviews.text: I used one time and the inside silver coating is rubbed off partly in the opening end part. It may be because water condensation would cause melting of the silver coating when I folded back the bag in a plastic bag. So I recommend every time once used, you need to make sure the emergency bag got dry before folding back. I want to show the pic but it seems Amazon stop us to upload pic in comments now. There is no upload pic function now. So bad!
customer_reviews.author: Patrick C

customer_reviews.title: Essential Emergency Gear
customer_reviews.text: This is a good bivy sack. But remember, this is for emergencies and survival situations. It is not a substitute sleeping bag. It is not a sleeping bag liner, that is, it is not meant for you to slide your sleeping bag into it. This is emergency gear and your well-being or life is on the line. If used correctly, it could help save your life. If I ever need to use this bivy, I hope that it is only for a one-time use. Recommended.
customer_reviews.author: HenryR

customer_reviews.title: Keeps you warm enough
customer_reviews.text: I was up in the mountains visiting family and needed to use this while there. It's nice enough to take the chili away and at one point I was actually sweating, which made me feel cold. This can make a difference to many people who don't have the comforts of home and just need a warm space.
customer_reviews.author: Steven Arellano

customer_reviews.title: Works well Great item to keep in the car for emergencies.
customer_reviews.text: Have purchased these at a sporting goods retailer in the past, and actually have used them when stuck in a cabin during an unexpected snow/ice storm when lost power. customer_reviews.author: PJNYC

customer_reviews.title: Seam will pull apart as tape is weak and narrow.
customer_reviews.text: Mine came in a box. Pulled it out to examine, not use. Measurements were 81" (6'9") long by 33" (2'9") wide, smaller than advertisement (see pic 1). Black tape around edges and tapes the two edges together (see pic 2). One can easily pull apart the seam where the edges come together (see pic 3). Better and wider tape would result in 5 stars.

customer_reviews.title: This won't work in Antarctica, but for most places it could be handy.
customer_reviews.text: This is a great addition to a BOB during moderate weather. It won't keep you warm at night in Alberta in the winter, but it is large enough that you could add some layers, like a wool blanket and survive. The heat reflective lining really works, but there is almost no insulation. Still, it is extremely compact and is better than just a space blanket.
customer_reviews.author: Verified Purchaser

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for mobile preparedness pack.

I wanted something that, if I actually had to use it, would be more substantial than the small flimsy foil type emergency blankets. We do a lot of riding in very remote areas that can get really cold at night. In the event that I have to spend the night out there, I feel confident I won't freeze to death.

customer_reviews.title: rolls up fairly easily and it keeps you warmer than a simple space ...
customer_reviews.text: This is compact, rolls up fairly easily and it keeps you warmer than a simple space blanket. It can probably used for quite a while in an emergency but it would benefit from some drying in the sun after a while to kill any odor buldup. For more flexibility, it may be better to invest in mylar blankets and duct tape in an emergency pack. I imagine it would be a pain to put together out in the field to replicate this bag though.

customer_reviews.text: My husband rides his KTM motorcycle all over the country.While riding the TransAmerica Trail this past October from Little Rock Arkansas to Gunnison, Colorado he got stopped by some harsh terrain and really thought he would have to spend the night on the mountain. BUT I checked it out and it is sturdy and perfect for an emergency.

No way I was gonna fold it back to its original packaging, so tossed it and bought another to have on standby again.

customer_reviews.title: Exactly as advertised! This is an EMERGENCY sleeping bag ...

Don't expect it to be all fluffy and soft - it's not and it's not intended to be. It is waterproof - and small enough to carry in your regular sleeping bag if you want extra protection. customer_reviews.title: this can easily fit in a jacket pocket or stuffed in with ...
